questions.questionText: What is the minimum size copper grounding electrode conductor for a 200-ampere service?
questions.explanation: NEC Table 250.66 specifies a minimum #4 AWG copper grounding electrode conductor for service entrance conductors up to 2/0 AWG copper or 4/0 AWG aluminum.
questions.sparkyTip: 200-amp service = #4 copper GEC. Match the service size to Table 250.66!

questions.questionText: What is the minimum burial depth for a ground rod?
questions.explanation: NEC 250.53(G) requires rod electrodes to be installed so that at least 8 feet (2.44 m) of length is in contact with the soil.
questions.sparkyTip: Ground rods need 8 feet in the earth - think 'great 8' for ground rods!

questions.questionText: When a single ground rod has a resistance greater than 25 ohms, what is required?
questions.explanation: NEC 250.53(A)(2) requires that if a single rod electrode has a resistance to earth greater than 25 ohms, it shall be augmented by one additional electrode.
questions.sparkyTip: Over 25 ohms? Add another rod! Two rods are the solution to high resistance.

questions.questionText: What is the minimum spacing between two ground rods?
questions.explanation: NEC 250.53(A)(3) requires that when more than one rod electrode is used, they shall be spaced not less than 6 feet apart.
questions.sparkyTip: 6 feet between rods minimum - give them room to do their job effectively!

questions.questionText: The grounding electrode conductor connects the grounding electrode to the:
questions.explanation: The grounding electrode conductor connects the grounding electrode system to the grounded service conductor (neutral) at the service equipment, as specified in NEC 250.24(A).
questions.sparkyTip: GEC goes from ground rod to neutral bar at service - that's where earth meets the system!

questions.questionText: What is the maximum length of a copper bonding jumper for a 2-inch trade size rigid metal conduit at a service?
questions.explanation: For service equipment, the bonding jumper size is determined by NEC Table 250.102(C)(1), which is based on the size of the largest service entrance conductor.
questions.sparkyTip: Service bonding = Table 250.102(C). Different from equipment grounding conductor sizing!

questions.questionText: What is the minimum size equipment grounding conductor for a 60-ampere circuit?
questions.explanation: NEC Table 250.122 specifies a minimum #10 AWG copper equipment grounding conductor for overcurrent devices rated 60 amperes.
questions.sparkyTip: Table 250.122 is your EGC sizing guide - match the breaker size to find your wire!

questions.questionText: A metal underground water pipe must be supplemented by an additional electrode if it is the sole grounding electrode and extends less than how many feet?
questions.explanation: NEC 250.52(A)(1) requires a metal underground water pipe to be in direct contact with the earth for 10 feet or more to qualify as a grounding electrode without supplementation.
questions.sparkyTip: Water pipe electrode needs 10 feet in earth - if less, it needs a buddy electrode!

questions.questionText: The main bonding jumper at service equipment connects the neutral bus to the:
questions.explanation: NEC 250.28 requires the main bonding jumper to connect the grounded conductor (neutral) to the equipment grounding conductor and the equipment enclosure at the service.
questions.sparkyTip: Main bonding jumper bridges neutral to ground at service - the only place they should meet!

questions.questionText: At what point must the grounded conductor (neutral) and equipment grounding conductor be bonded together?
questions.explanation: NEC 250.24(A)(5) and 250.142(B) prohibit connecting the grounded conductor to equipment grounding conductors or equipment on the load side of the service disconnecting means, except in specific circumstances.
questions.sparkyTip: Neutral-ground bond ONLY at service! In subpanels, keep them separate.

questions.questionText: What is the minimum size copper bonding conductor for a gas piping system where the upstream gas pipe bonding point is supplied by a 100A circuit?
questions.explanation: NEC 250.104(B) requires bonding of metal gas piping. The bonding conductor size is based on Table 250.122 using the rating of the circuit that could energize the piping. For 100A, that's #6 AWG copper.
questions.sparkyTip: Gas pipe bonding uses Table 250.122 - size it like an equipment grounding conductor!

questions.questionText: What is the diameter of a standard ground rod?
questions.explanation: NEC 250.52(A)(5) requires rod electrodes to have a minimum diameter of ⅝ inch (15.87 mm) for standard ground rods. Stainless steel or nonferrous rods can be ½ inch.
questions.sparkyTip: Standard ground rod = ⅝ inch diameter. It's the industry standard!

questions.questionText: What color is required for insulated equipment grounding conductors?
options: Green or green with yellow stripes
questions.explanation: NEC 250.119 requires equipment grounding conductors to be identified by a continuous green color or green with one or more yellow stripes.
questions.sparkyTip: Green for ground - it's easy to remember: G for Green, G for Ground!

questions.questionText: For a separately derived system (transformer), the grounding electrode conductor size is based on:
options: Table 250.66 based on derived phase conductors
questions.explanation: NEC 250.30(A)(6) requires the grounding electrode conductor for separately derived systems to be sized per Table 250.66, based on the derived phase conductors.
questions.sparkyTip: Separately derived systems use Table 250.66 too - based on secondary conductor size!

questions.questionText: Bonding of metal water piping in a building must be done with a conductor not smaller than:
questions.explanation: NEC 250.104(A)(1) requires the bonding conductor for interior metal water piping to be sized per Table 250.66, based on the size of the service entrance conductors.
questions.sparkyTip: Water pipe bonding = Table 250.66. Size it like your GEC!

questions.questionText: The intersystem bonding termination device must be capable of terminating how many conductors?
questions.explanation: NEC 250.94 requires an intersystem bonding termination that provides connection capacity for at least 3 intersystem bonding conductors (for cable, telephone, etc.).
questions.sparkyTip: Intersystem bonding = 3 terminations minimum. One for each utility that might need it!

questions.questionText: Where is the system grounding connection typically made for a grounded electrical system?
questions.explanation: NEC 250.24(A)(1) requires the grounding electrode conductor connection to be made at any accessible point from the load end of the service drop to the service disconnecting means.
questions.sparkyTip: System ground connects at the service - that's home base for your grounding!

questions.questionText: Which table is used to size equipment grounding conductors (EGCs) based on overcurrent device rating?
questions.explanation: EGC sizing is based on the rating of the overcurrent device per Table 250.122.
questions.sparkyTip: Anchor the rule to its NEC section before you size or bond anything.

questions.questionText: Which table is used to size grounding electrode conductors (GECs) based on service conductor size (select the best answer)
questions.explanation: GEC sizing for services is based on Table 250.66.
questions.sparkyTip: Anchor the rule to its NEC section before you size or bond anything.

questions.questionText: For a separately derived system, which table is used to size the grounding electrode conductor?

questions.questionText: Bonding for interior metal water piping systems is sized using which table (select the best answer)

questions.explanation: All available electrodes must be bonded together to form a grounding electrode system.

questions.questionText: A dwelling unit has 1400 sq ft of floor area, 2 small-appliance circuits, and 1 laundry circuit. questions.explanation: Voltage drop = 2 x I x R x D / 1000 = 8.36 V.
questions.sparkyTip: Use 2 x distance for single-phase voltage drop.

questions.questionText: A 3-phase feeder carries 60 A and runs 150 ft one-way. The conductor resistance is 0.197 ohms per 1000 ft. What is the approximate line-to-line voltage drop in volts?
questions.explanation: Voltage drop = 1.732 x I x R x D / 1000 = 3.07 V.
questions.sparkyTip: 3-phase voltage drop uses 1.732 x I x R x D / 1000.

questions.questionText: A 3-phase feeder carries 64 A and runs 165 ft one-way. The conductor resistance is 0.197 ohms per 1000 ft. What is the approximate line-to-line voltage drop in volts?
questions.explanation: Voltage drop = 1.732 x I x R x D / 1000 = 3.6 V.
questions.sparkyTip: 3-phase voltage drop uses 1.732 x I x R x D / 1000.

questions.questionText: A 3-phase feeder carries 68 A and runs 180 ft one-way. The conductor resistance is 0.197 ohms per 1000 ft. What is the approximate line-to-line voltage drop in volts?
questions.explanation: Voltage drop = 1.732 x I x R x D / 1000 = 4.18 V.
questions.sparkyTip: 3-phase voltage drop uses 1.732 x I x R x D / 1000.

questions.questionText: A 3-phase feeder carries 72 A and runs 195 ft one-way. The conductor resistance is 0.197 ohms per 1000 ft. What is the approximate line-to-line voltage drop in volts?
questions.explanation: Voltage drop = 1.732 x I x R x D / 1000 = 4.79 V.
questions.sparkyTip: 3-phase voltage drop uses 1.732 x I x R x D / 1000.

questions.questionText: A 3-phase feeder carries 76 A and runs 210 ft one-way. The conductor resistance is 0.197 ohms per 1000 ft. What is the approximate line-to-line voltage drop in volts?
questions.explanation: Voltage drop = 1.732 x I x R x D / 1000 = 5.45 V.
questions.sparkyTip: 3-phase voltage drop uses 1.732 x I x R x D / 1000.

questions.questionText: A 3-phase feeder carries 80 A and runs 225 ft one-way. The conductor resistance is 0.197 ohms per 1000 ft. What is the approximate line-to-line voltage drop in volts?
questions.explanation: Voltage drop = 1.732 x I x R x D / 1000 = 6.14 V.
questions.sparkyTip: 3-phase voltage drop uses 1.732 x I x R x D / 1000.

questions.questionText: A 3-phase feeder carries 84 A and runs 240 ft one-way. The conductor resistance is 0.197 ohms per 1000 ft. What is the approximate line-to-line voltage drop in volts?
questions.explanation: Voltage drop = 1.732 x I x R x D / 1000 = 6.88 V.
questions.sparkyTip: 3-phase voltage drop uses 1.732 x I x R x D / 1000.

questions.questionText: A 3-phase feeder carries 88 A and runs 255 ft one-way. The conductor resistance is 0.197 ohms per 1000 ft. What is the approximate line-to-line voltage drop in volts?
questions.explanation: Voltage drop = 1.732 x I x R x D / 1000 = 7.66 V.
questions.sparkyTip: 3-phase voltage drop uses 1.732 x I x R x D / 1000.

questions.questionText: A 3-phase feeder carries 92 A and runs 270 ft one-way. The conductor resistance is 0.197 ohms per 1000 ft. What is the approximate line-to-line voltage drop in volts?
questions.explanation: Voltage drop = 1.732 x I x R x D / 1000 = 8.48 V.
questions.sparkyTip: 3-phase voltage drop uses 1.732 x I x R x D / 1000.

questions.questionText: A 3-phase feeder carries 96 A and runs 285 ft one-way. The conductor resistance is 0.197 ohms per 1000 ft. What is the approximate line-to-line voltage drop in volts?
questions.explanation: Voltage drop = 1.732 x I x R x D / 1000 = 9.34 V.
questions.sparkyTip: 3-phase voltage drop uses 1.732 x I x R x D / 1000.

questions.questionText: A conductor has a base ampacity of 120 A (75 C column). The temperature correction factor is 0.88 and the adjustment factor is 0.8. What is the adjusted ampacity?
questions.explanation: Adjusted ampacity = 120 x 0.88 x 0.8 = 84 A.
questions.sparkyTip: Multiply base ampacity by all applicable correction/adjustment factors.

questions.questionText: A conductor has a base ampacity of 125 A (75 C column). The temperature correction factor is 0.88 and the adjustment factor is 0.8. What is the adjusted ampacity?
questions.explanation: Adjusted ampacity = 125 x 0.88 x 0.8 = 88 A.
questions.sparkyTip: Multiply base ampacity by all applicable correction/adjustment factors.

questions.questionText: A conductor has a base ampacity of 130 A (75 C column). The temperature correction factor is 0.88 and the adjustment factor is 0.8. What is the adjusted ampacity?
questions.explanation: Adjusted ampacity = 130 x 0.88 x 0.8 = 92 A.
questions.sparkyTip: Multiply base ampacity by all applicable correction/adjustment factors.

questions.questionText: A conductor has a base ampacity of 135 A (75 C column). The temperature correction factor is 0.88 and the adjustment factor is 0.8. What is the adjusted ampacity?
questions.explanation: Adjusted ampacity = 135 x 0.88 x 0.8 = 95 A.
questions.sparkyTip: Multiply base ampacity by all applicable correction/adjustment factors.

questions.questionText: A conductor has a base ampacity of 140 A (75 C column). The temperature correction factor is 0.88 and the adjustment factor is 0.8. What is the adjusted ampacity?
questions.explanation: Adjusted ampacity = 140 x 0.88 x 0.8 = 99 A.
questions.sparkyTip: Multiply base ampacity by all applicable correction/adjustment factors.

questions.questionText: A conductor has a base ampacity of 145 A (75 C column). The temperature correction factor is 0.88 and the adjustment factor is 0.8. What is the adjusted ampacity?
questions.explanation: Adjusted ampacity = 145 x 0.88 x 0.8 = 102 A.

questions.questionText: A conductor has a base ampacity of 150 A (75 C column). The temperature correction factor is 0.88 and the adjustment factor is 0.8. What is the adjusted ampacity?
questions.explanation: Adjusted ampacity = 150 x 0.88 x 0.8 = 106 A.
questions.sparkyTip: Multiply base ampacity by all applicable correction/adjustment factors.

questions.questionText: A conductor has a base ampacity of 155 A (75 C column). The temperature correction factor is 0.88 and the adjustment factor is 0.8. What is the adjusted ampacity?
questions.explanation: Adjusted ampacity = 155 x 0.88 x 0.8 = 109 A.
questions.sparkyTip: Multiply base ampacity by all applicable correction/adjustment factors.

questions.questionText: A conductor has a base ampacity of 160 A (75 C column). The temperature correction factor is 0.88 and the adjustment factor is 0.8. What is the adjusted ampacity?
questions.explanation: Adjusted ampacity = 160 x 0.88 x 0.8 = 113 A.
questions.sparkyTip: Multiply base ampacity by all applicable correction/adjustment factors.

questions.questionText: A conductor has a base ampacity of 165 A (75 C column). The temperature correction factor is 0.88 and the adjustment factor is 0.8. What is the adjusted ampacity?
questions.explanation: Adjusted ampacity = 165 x 0.88 x 0.8 = 116 A.
questions.sparkyTip: Multiply base ampacity by all applicable correction/adjustment factors.

questions.questionText: A box contains 6 current-carrying 12 AWG conductors, 3 equipment grounds, one internal clamp, and one device yoke. Using 2.25 cu in per 12 AWG conductor, what is the minimum required box volume?
questions.explanation: Count conductors: 6 + grounds(1) + clamp(1) + device yoke(2) = 10 equivalents. Volume = 10 x 2.25 = 22.5 cu in.
questions.sparkyTip: All grounds count as one; device yokes count as two.

questions.questionText: A box contains 7 current-carrying 12 AWG conductors, 3 equipment grounds, one internal clamp, and one device yoke. Using 2.25 cu in per 12 AWG conductor, what is the minimum required box volume?
questions.explanation: Count conductors: 7 + grounds(1) + clamp(1) + device yoke(2) = 11 equivalents. Volume = 11 x 2.25 = 24.75 cu in.
questions.sparkyTip: All grounds count as one; device yokes count as two.

questions.questionText: A box contains 8 current-carrying 12 AWG conductors, 3 equipment grounds, one internal clamp, and one device yoke. Using 2.25 cu in per 12 AWG conductor, what is the minimum required box volume?
questions.explanation: Count conductors: 8 + grounds(1) + clamp(1) + device yoke(2) = 12 equivalents. Volume = 12 x 2.25 = 27.0 cu in.
questions.sparkyTip: All grounds count as one; device yokes count as two.

questions.questionText: A box contains 6 current-carrying 12 AWG conductors, 3 equipment grounds, one internal clamp, and one device yoke. Using 2.25 cu in per 12 AWG conductor, what is the minimum required box volume?
questions.explanation: Count conductors: 6 + grounds(1) + clamp(1) + device yoke(2) = 10 equivalents. Volume = 10 x 2.25 = 22.5 cu in.
questions.sparkyTip: All grounds count as one; device yokes count as two.

questions.questionText: A box contains 7 current-carrying 12 AWG conductors, 3 equipment grounds, one internal clamp, and one device yoke. Using 2.25 cu in per 12 AWG conductor, what is the minimum required box volume?
questions.explanation: Count conductors: 7 + grounds(1) + clamp(1) + device yoke(2) = 11 equivalents. Volume = 11 x 2.25 = 24.75 cu in.
questions.sparkyTip: All grounds count as one; device yokes count as two.

questions.explanation: Count conductors: 8 + grounds(1) + clamp(1) + device yoke(2) = 12 equivalents. Volume = 12 x 2.25 = 27.0 cu in.
questions.sparkyTip: All grounds count as one; device yokes count as two.

questions.explanation: Count conductors: 6 + grounds(1) + clamp(1) + device yoke(2) = 10 equivalents. Volume = 10 x 2.25 = 22.5 cu in.
questions.sparkyTip: All grounds count as one; device yokes count as two.

questions.explanation: Count conductors: 7 + grounds(1) + clamp(1) + device yoke(2) = 11 equivalents. Volume = 11 x 2.25 = 24.75 cu in.
questions.sparkyTip: All grounds count as one; device yokes count as two.
